reviewText:
Relic Hunter Zero is a top down shooter in the same vein as Nuclear Throne thats been sprinkled with a tiny bit of Binding of Isaac's progression and unlocks. Despite being a freebie, this game ranks up there with some of the best top down shooters out there at the moment. And while seeming simple at first glance, the game actually has a lot more to it than first meets the eye. Each game mechanic that Rogue Snail chose to include in their (surprisingly free) game has multiple facets that add up quickly to create a well-polished, functional, and challenging skill-based shooter.

The gun play feels good, the sounds are strong, the screen shake adds to the impact, and the enemies fall when you'd expect them to, simply put: its visceral and satisfying. Each weapon has an effective range after which the damage falls off and enemies also take extra if hit in a certain place too, The damage indicators are nice and fit the flow of the game well. Grenades can travel over destructible cover to hit dangerous groups of enemies, and theres even an aim mode which lets you see further and increase your accuracy slightly. Ammo management is also a thing, rather than just having an infinitely firing weapon, each gun has its own magazine and reload times. You can use up whats in a mag and swap with a weapon on the ground without spending ammo from your ammo pools too. This can be a great way to stock pile early on and is surprisingly fun to swap weapons out all the time (but you dont need to!)

Movement mechanics seem fairly solid. You have stamina for sprint alongside a dash/dodge ability. The player is given everything they need to dodge, seek cover, return fire, and close the distance with the enemy if they want to get up close and personal with a shotgun or their fists. Beware though as melee also pulls from your stamina so you cant just dash in, hit and dash out. If i have -any- gripe at all its to say that using the keyboard and mouse, you can only seemingly dash in the 8 cardinal directions. Sprint and dash are bound to the same button which causes the accidental dash sometimes when you dont want it, or the inability to dash (because you end up sprinting instead.) But even with that said, the movement feels pretty good, even if it could use a bit of tweaking, an alternative key bind, and possibly an option to 'dash towards cursor' There is however a melee weapon that serves that function.

Each character has health and a rechargeable shield which can be upgraded slightly throughout the adventure. If your shield ever breaks though you will lose any boosted over-charge ability, so dont get complacent.. just rushing in and taking fire when you've got a big shield will lead to losing your shield powerups before you know it. Both your health and shield are determined by your choice of character and can be modified with relics that you unlock, as well as in-game pickups.

When it comes to unlocks you can unlock multiple characters, as well as guns, ammo, and relics to start the game with and make things easier. Like in Spelunky theres an unlockable level skip which can help you get back into the action a little more quickly if you find yourself too good for the early levels, and may put you at a slight disadvantage for increased challenge in the later ones. One thing that confused me at first was that the store not only sells you items for your current run, but if you buy an item it also unlocks for your next play through and you can start with it if desired.

The AI is even a decent challenge too. Enemy variety is moderate, Ive only seen a handful of types in the few hours that I've played but what is there is well placed when coupled with the variety of weapons they can use (and will occasionally drop when defeated.) Different enemy soldiers will fight together as a more effective group, and sometimes the enemy will even run away for cover if it needs to. The AI can even interact with itself on occasion which is a really nice touch that adds a bit more variety to the gameplay, can even be used to your advantage sometimes.

All in all the developers at Rogue Snail really hit a homerun with Relic Hunters Zero. The music didnt quite resonate with me fully on all of their tracks, but they nailed their gameplay mechanics in this title without any question. They even made it an open source project as well, meaning that we will likely see some great content mods come to this freebie because the ground work the Devs put in made for such an exceptional gaming experience. You can tell that the team put a lot of love and effort into creating their game; it shows in the influences taken from all over the genre being brought together in a way like we had not quite seen before.

Relic Hunters Zero might be a free to play game, but its more polished on launch than most of the paid titles we see on Steam these days. Dont let its price fool you, Rogue Snail put out a quality product here. You wont want to skip on this one if you're a fan of top down shooters. This is by far the best game I never bought this year, and turned out to be vastly more fun than many of the games I had been looking forward to.

Pros:
- Good weapon play / ammo management.
- Variety of characters to play / relics to equip.
- Sounds feel impactful.
- AI and enemy variety are decent.
- Destructible cover / dynamic fights.
- Unlockables to strive for.
- Challenging.
- Free and moddable.

Cons:
- Music might not fit everyone's taste.
- Dash/Dodge/Sprint movement has a few quirks using keyboard control.

reviewText:
This game was reviewed with a key from the developer (yes, it's a free game, but I played it before it was released).

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: http://youtu.be/GVeS2s2LrI0

Summary:
Gotta love a free experience, especially one as solid as this. Don't get me wrong, there are elements to improve with some bad color choices at times and some difficulty spikes that can cause people problems, but that doesn't undo the great top down shooter gameplay that the guys behind Chroma Squad and Dungeonland have to offer. Different Characters and weaponry can lead to some variety in gameplay, while the core shooting mechanics keep the action up while not being too boring. Randomization in spawn location and enemy location helps the game in question, while not going to far in making it too unpredictable. It's a solid game that you can even look at the source code at, and for a game that doesn't have microtransactions? Yeah, it's definitely worth your time.
Lists:

+:
Core combat and controls work: give you a feeling of power and allows for different skill sets without being overbearing.
No microtransactions for a great experience all around. It's free. Great for local co-op with the chaos it creates.
Good progression that allows for real growth in terms of gameplay and feeling strong.
Variety in character builds can lead to different play styles despite the simple gameplay.
Good set of options actually, in particular with the ability to remove the screen shake.
Strong aesthetic that reminds me of a comic book style in some ways, like a cross between Scott Pilgrim and modern comic aesthetic.
Music is appropriate and really is just a good mix all around.
Source code is available for people who really want to see what the game is under the surface.
-:
Grenades may be too over powered, for both you and the enemy. They can screw you up rather easily.
Once in a while, the aesthetic works against itself, in causing issues with attempting to see your envrionment (red laser on red background).
Later levels can have get hit of screen that can really cause frustration.
Difficulty spikes will frustrate at times.

The very fact that this game is free, there is nothing stopping you from giving this game your time, and trust me, it warrants it. Do you like arcade-style gameplay? Done. Fast-paced run-n'-gun action? Absolutely. Addictive levels of replayability? Triple check. tl;dr at the bottom.

The main plot is easy enough to follow: You're a Relic Hunter, and you hunt relics. Simple enough, right? One hitch: the asteroid you're on is teeming with vicious wildlife and cutthroat thugs. The solution? Shoot everything that moves.

You select from one of 6 hunters, that're all gradually unlocked over time. Each one starts with their own weapon, like Jimmy's Elite Pistol, Raff's Keytar Cannon, and my personal favorite, Pinkyy's devestating melee gloves. Each Hunter has their own unique playstyle, and may take a bit of practice with each to truly master them.

The game features a main campaign made up of 4 stages, 3 levels each, including a final boss. Between each level, you can search for new relic pieces, and after stages can purchase weapons and equipment that carry over into future runs.

The name of the game is the Relics, handy doodads with a variety of effects. Find their 3 pieces, and the relic is yours! You can only carry 3 relics at one time, however, meaning you need to plan and synergize your relics around that plan.

Beat the Campaign? Time for the meat of the game: Endless Mode. This is where the game kicks into full throttle: new mechanics, like Mods that alter gameplay; new guns, like the legendary Relic Weapons; and even new Relics like the Morning Star, which boosts all Bounty pickups massively! But by-far, the most menacing is the addition of new enemies, including Ducan Elites, who'll hunt you down relentlessly!

There's also an expanded post-stage hub, allowing you to spend your Bounty to restock, hack out Mods, purchase Relics, and swap out Relics you've already found. That Crude Pistol a bit weak? Give it a couple upgrades at the gunsmith, and you'll crack skulls like a champ!

RHZ comes with Co-Op mode for both Campaign and Endless, local-only, which lets you bring a buddy along to share in the joys of genocide! As the old saying goes: there's power in numbers! Just make sure not to accidentally" kill them. Especially for an achievement

Relic Hunter Zero is a surprising free entry to Steam because it is really really good. It's a 2d shooter rogue lite, meaning that later in the game is really difficult. Your character across runs gets guns as you play through the stages, and at the end of each stage there's a chance to find a piece of a relic that upgrades your character. Along with that you can get bounty, the in game money, to get things in your ship before you begin.

The shooting and movement mechanics go hand in hand. You are really floaty in movement, you can dash and sprint around, and dashing makes you invincible to weapons. The guns are very fun as well. There's three types of guns with their own ammo like Destiny, light, medium, and heavy ammo. It has a mechanic where putting your crosshair over the enemy instead of behind and in front does more damage.

The game has huge potential as far as other features go. I would like to see an online multiplayer along with the couch co op (however controllers aren't really the best way to play this game) and some sort of multiplayer. The balance would be an easy change, as the enemy AI in singleplayer is about as hard other people get.

reviewText:
I just grabbed this game for a fun little romp, but I can already see hours of my time going into it.

This game is excellent. It looks like your typical top-down shooter indie game, but it's so much more.

Around a half hour in I realized that I kept dying to the minor enemies in around stage two, and that was when I realized how much this game has to offer. If you plan on running in and firing away into crowds like you do in every other top down shooter, you won't make it far in this game. Long reload times, relative ammo scarcity, and strong standard enemies mean you have to put a reasonable amount of thought into each encounter.

It's not a strategy game by any means, but I regularly find myself looking at the latest cluster of enemies and quickly planning my shots in the back of my head before I go in, as to leave the best chance of making it out alive. However, it doesn't require so much thought that you spend any time waiting, thinking of what to do. All it requires is that you're actively aware, and that's really fantastic. The game trusts that you'll learn how the weapons, mechanics, and enemies function, in order to really master the game. It's also not the grueling challenge that you see many games that require that understanding become. Relic Hunters Zero is a happy medium between the difficult game that asks you to master, and the fun shoot-em-up romp we've come to expect from a game of it's style.

In summary, Relic Hunters Zero is a great way to spend some time if you want a top-down shooter with a little more substance. 10/10.

P.S. I'm hoping the fact that it's open source will lead to lots of additional content in the future.

Relic Hunters Zero an open-source FREE Indie Shooter brought to you by the guys that made Chroma Squad, Dungeonlands and Knights of Pen & Paper.

For a free game without any free to play ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•t they don't get much better or original.

On the surface Relic Hunters is a twin stick shooter. However, after getting deeper in you find it's a little dungeon crawly, a little rouge-like and a whole lot of awesome.

Tasked to kill space ducks and turtles (and weird beast thingies) you choose between 2 starting characters (one ranged focused, one melee) and are on a.....um hunt for relics.

Collecting a relic set allows you to enable that relic giving you an edge during your gameplay, so like a rougelike as you discover more relics it gets easier to progress.

The art style is a great pixel design, with the soundtrack to back it up.

Overall - Relic Hunters Zero is a great FREE indie shooter, with a lot of gameplay, so much so that other indie dev's selling their games should probably be mad they are giving it away.

Nuclear Throne: Prepare to Die Edition -featuring- Duck Hunt is a fun and challenging indie title by Rogue Snail.

The story is as follows: The Duck-Hunt Ducks have declared war on humanity, and their leader, Commander Duckin', have attacked a human colony on some stupid planet. It's up to a handful of handsomely rugged relic hunters with horrible cases of anime hair and their positively romantically named ship, the Spaceheart, to defeat them! Oh, and the Duck-Hunt Ducks have allied (read; forced into war-labour) with some space turtles, and they all have better guns than you. Have fun!

Players can take control of one of six available characters, each with a different stat balance and starting weapon. The player starts with access with Jammy, an all-rounded character with nothing interesting to offer AT ALL, and Punkyy, who specialises in melee and pistol combat like the edgelady she is. From there, Laff the Keyboard Warrior, By-You the 'Nade Spammer, Pinny the 420kg Blazer and Ace the Ace-Hole can all be unlocked though gameplay.

During gameplay, it is possible to obtain a substantial collection of 'more gun' to assist in gibbing thousands of ducks and turtles. Nine times outta ten, you get them from gibbing ducks and turtles. The controls are tight and innovative, and the game's focus is on dodging and using cover, rather than mowing through waves of enemies. The relics recovered from Commander Duckin''s forces actually grant bonuses to the player, and are a good incentive to become a completionist. The art style is pretty neat as well, and the music is pretty damn great. A few gripes of mine are with the fact that lobbed grenades have a locked toss distance, and using the scope doesn't constantly 'refresh,' I guess? Also, the images of the characters used in the menus are obviously sketches. Also, the game is pretty short in terms of levels, as there are only 4 zones, each with 3 levels, with a bossfight at the end of all of them. That said, the difficulty makes the game last for a fair while. Nothing major anyways.

I'll be completely honest, I haven't really tried co-op. All I really did was use it to get the Oops achievement.

Normally, I would give a game like this 7/10, but as it is truly free-to-play and open-source, I must give it an Eight Dead Ducks and One Turtle Outta Ten. Truly worth playing.

Relic Hunters Zero is arcade shooter that plays like Nuclear Throne.
It is a stop down twinstick shooter with weapons that use different ammo types which are light, medium, and heavy. There is plenty of ammo to gather and enemies do drop their own weapons from time to time making it easy to switch weapon types if you are running low on a specific ammo type.

So far I have made it to level 4-2 in what looks to be a four zone game, and it seems there are only two different enemy types. The ducks and the beast.
The ducks come in numerous types and carry a good variety of the weapons so each zone has diffrent types for you to try out. Unfortuatnly what I call the beast enemies don't have the variety of the ducks coming in with just two different beast.

To lengthen your play time there is a bit of grinding to be had. Killing enemies rewards you with bounty. Bounty is used to open up checkpoints between zones which is great if you just are just trying to play to the end as quickly as possible.
And of course there are weapons to buy as well to get you set up for a better run starting. And I cannot forget about upgrades. These include extra ammo packs, extra grenades, and the super useful sheild upgrades. Good stuff.
And then there is the last and best items of the game. The relics. Relic pieces can be found randomly in levels and bits of them can be bought from the donkey. Once you collect three in a set you can use them to give yourself a little boost for your next run. Things like starting with more health and arrmor or even extra ammo. There are more of course. The sounds track is alright. Nothing amazing but thankfully it isn't something that has to be muted. Just my opinon of course. Some people adore this kind of music. Listen to the trailer yourself... or better yet download and play. The best part of this game is that it is completely free. There is no in-game shop to use real cash on anything, which is great of course.
If there is one true complaint to be had is the lack of online co-op. There is local co-op of course and it is great. But a lot of people don't have someone to come over often for local games and connecting with friends online is the best option.

reviewText:
Nuclear Throne: Prepare to Die Edition -featuring- Duck Hunt is a fun and challenging indie title by Rogue Snail.

The story is as follows: The Duck-Hunt Ducks have declared war on humanity, and their leader, Commander Duckin', have attacked a human colony on some stupid planet. It's up to a handful of handsomely rugged relic hunters with horrible cases of anime hair and their positively romantically named ship, the Spaceheart, to defeat them! Oh, and the Duck-Hunt Ducks have allied (read; forced into war-labour) with some space turtles, and they all have better guns than you. Have fun!

Players can take control of one of six available characters, each with a different stat balance and starting weapon. The player starts with access with Jammy, an all-rounded character with nothing interesting to offer AT ALL, and Punkyy, who specialises in melee and pistol combat like the edgelady she is. From there, Laff the Keyboard Warrior, By-You the 'Nade Spammer, Pinny the 420kg Blazer and Ace the Ace-Hole can all be unlocked though gameplay.

During gameplay, it is possible to obtain a substantial collection of 'more gun' to assist in gibbing thousands of ducks and turtles. Nine times outta ten, you get them from gibbing ducks and turtles. The controls are tight and innovative, and the game's focus is on dodging and using cover, rather than mowing through waves of enemies. The relics recovered from Commander Duckin''s forces actually grant bonuses to the player, and are a good incentive to become a completionist. The art style is pretty neat as well, and the music is pretty damn great. A few gripes of mine are with the fact that lobbed grenades have a locked toss distance, and using the scope doesn't constantly 'refresh,' I guess? Also, the images of the characters used in the menus are obviously sketches. Also, the game is pretty short in terms of levels, as there are only 4 zones, each with 3 levels, with a bossfight at the end of all of them. That said, the difficulty makes the game last for a fair while. Nothing major anyways.

I'll be completely honest, I haven't really tried co-op. All I really did was use it to get the Oops achievement.

Normally, I would give a game like this 7/10, but as it is truly free-to-play and open-source, I must give it an Eight Dead Ducks and One Turtle Outta Ten. Truly worth playing.

reviewText:
The game is really fun, it can be very fast-paced or you can slowly shoot your enemies and go back to regain your shield, whether you're crazy or not depends on you.

At first it may look simple, there aren't many enemies, but at the last levels the enemies that exist can be extremely dangerous.

The characters have their own weapon exclusive only to themselves (except Ace, he is just bad) and they are very good if you can use them properly, each character also feels very different since some of them can't use some weapons properly, and you'll end up shooting everywhere but where you want to.

The game feels challenging at first, once you get the relics things will become easier, but not as easy to make the gameplay boring (you may even feel too powerful and rush and die, it happens to me).

Pros:
- Fun and fast-paced
- Each character is unique in some way
- Last character can be challenging
- Simple graphics (which makes things easy to see)
- Permanent upgrades
- It's open source!!!! :D
- Free :D

Cons:
- Poorly optimized (needs a lot of resources even if it only has pixel draws)
- Multiplayer support only with xbox controller (some controllers won't work properly or at all)
- Bounty becomes useless in Adventure once you have everything

The developers also keep doing more updates which is always good :D

reviewText:
I love this game already.

Pros
-------
+The game is very easy to control with both a gamepad and a mouse and keyboard.
+It feels like Nuclear Throne.
+There are multiple characters, multiple relics, and multiple weapons/ammo crates to unlock for your use before heading out into the stages.
+You can purchase checkpoints with Bounty (in-game currency) to either continue your game from where you left off or you can start a fresh run from the beginning of stage one and go all the way to stage four.
+Speaking of currency, there's no paid DLC type of shortcuts. Everything is up to you!
+You kill ducks daily.
+Supports local co-op

Cons
-------

-The game can be a bit repetitive and lacks replayability after unlocking most (if not all) of the unlockables. Hoping for a Daily soon!
-The worlds aren't randomly generated (the item spawns and player spawns are, though!) so you'll be able to figure out enemy locations and possible loot locations pretty fast.


This is definitely a game that you should give a try. The game is like 85MB in size and it's free. If you hate fun, then skip right over this of course.

tl;dr, the game is a ton of f**kin' fun!

THIS GAME , THIS GAME RIGHT HERE , AMAZING, 9/10 overall rating. i'd easily pay 15 bucks for this game , and  30 (or more depending on how much content it would have ) for a good continuation of this game if it ever comes out!

-Graphics:  9/10 the art style is really easy on the eyes. you can easily sit down for hours playing it , its not like some gritty boring realistic game trying to overwhelm me with next gen details and complex textures. SIMPLE. CUTE. COOL

- Gameplay- this game is best discribed as.... cave story from a top down perspective mixed with third person shooter elements? its very easy to pick up and has realistic undertones to the gameplay style. you can only hold 2 weapons , a pocket full of grenades and you have a recovering shield. weapons can be swapped out  from pick ups around the map and dead enemies. its really easy to kill things , and its really easy to die if youre not on your toes. you can sprint around your enemies, melee and dash to escape bad situations for aslong as you have stamina to do so , which regenerates over time. there are 6 characters to (easily) unlock that spice up both game modes (endless and adventure) along with a TON of unlockables that will have you backtracking through levels the majority of time while effortlessly unlocking all the characters along the way. SUPER FUN WITH MILDLY REALISTIC  FEATURES MAKES IT LESS OF A TOTAL RUN AND GUN  100% OF THE TIME.

-Audio: the sounds in this game are charming , simple and pleasing like everything else, the soundtrack is just the same aswell , 8bit tunes, tracks i totally remember humming as i blasted my way through the levels. totally worth searching up and downloading if youre into videogameOST's!

----------------
What I disliked

keep in mind i understand its a free to play. i just say these things for future reference if the Devs ever decide to drop a continuation of the game!
-no online  co-op: i played the game locally with a few friends but  still online co-op would be great (its still realy fun solo aswell but not nearly as fun with a friend)

friendly fire on or off: friendly fire is always on so you can kill your teammates mistakenly(or on purpose) alot. it wouldve been nice to have option to turn it off.

PVP: PVP for ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• and giggles? while some of the characters would be a bit unbalanced against others , it would be cool to face off in  arena of sorts and maybe play as enemy characters in a senseless battle royale!

- not enough levels and bosses! there are 5 worlds each with ( i think) 2 levels. there is only one boss , the final boss. it wouldve been nice to see more but yea , its a free to play that prolly didnt have that much of budget to work with.

overall the only real issue is that there is no online co-op , more levels wouldve been nice but the game has really good replay value and the endless mode makes it even more enjoyable.

I've only played for a little bit so far (completed the adventure mode already and had a quick go at the endless mode). Basically, what's not to love? It's a wonderfully retro top down shooty slice of fun with a nice upgrade system and gentle, well-judged humour. All in all, great little game with lots of heart! It's free, but it's better than quite a number of paid games in my library!

I'm about 5 hours into the game and I haven't beaten the Adventure mode final boss yet, but I've come close. There is still a lot of content left to unlock at this point and I haven't even opened the Endless mode yet.

The premise of the game is that you are put into a confined level and you have to clear the level of enemies. Most levels only take a couple minutes, though they get longer and more challenging the higher the level. There are about 16 regular Adventure mode levels so far. You earn credits for every enemy you kill, and you use that currency to unlock things like better weapons, more ammo, shields, and even things like the additional Endless mode, as well as level skips so you can jump right into level 2 or 3 or 4 instead of having to go back through levels you've already cleared.

White - far
